Susan Sarandon Biography

Susan Abigail Tomalin, who is known all around the world by her professional name Susan Sarandon, is a very famous and successful name in America. She was born in New York City, United States, on 4 October 1946. She was raised in New York, where she used to live with her family. She was born into a very big family, where she was the eldest child out of nine children of Lenora Marie and Philip Leslie Tomalin.

She was raised Roman catholic alongside her siblings. After schooling, she developed a love for acting and later started working in stage plays. As far as personal life is concerned, she calls herself bisexual. She was married to Chris Sarandon from 1967 to 1979. Susan Sarandon: Career and Awards

She did a handful of movies throughout the 70s and gained decent success. In 1977, she did The Great Smokey Roadblock, where she also worked as a Co-producer.

In 1980, she did Atlantic City, for which she was nominated for an Academy Award. In 1988, she did Bill Durham, for which she was nominated for a Golden Globe. She later did several successful movies such as White Palace, Thelma & Louise, The Client, Dead Man Walking, Stepmom, Enchanted, and many more. She later started working as a producer as well.

She made her TV debut in 1971 in A World Apart. She did a handful of TV films and shows in her early career. In 1985, she joined A.D., where she worked on five episodes.
